articles.author: fdemott@insider.com (Filip De Mott)
articles.title: Bitcoin could see a wave of forced selling as miners face the reality of lower rewards post-halving, research firm says
articles.description: "If miners were forced to sell even a fraction of their holdings over the coming month this would have a negative impact on markets," Kaiki Research wrote.
articles.content:
Markets have long considered bitcoin's recent halving as a major price bolster, but it could bring a wave of selling from one corner of the sector, according to Kaiko Research.
The April halving is … [+1708 chars]

articles.author: Andy Greenberg
articles.title: A Vast New Dataset Could Supercharge the AI Hunt for Crypto Money Laundering
articles.description: Blockchain analysis firm Elliptic, MIT, and IBM, have released a new AI detection model—and the 200-million-transaction dataset it's trained on—that aims to spot the “shape” of Bitcoin money laundering.
articles.content: As a test of their resulting AI tool, the researchers checked its outputs with one cryptocurrency exchangewhich the paper doesn't nameidentifying 52 suspicious chains of transactions that had all ult… [+3279 chars]

articles.author: Joel Khalili
articles.title: Craig Wright Lied About Creating Bitcoin And Faked Evidence, Judge Rules
articles.description: A UK judge has determined that Craig Wright forged evidence in a campaign to prove he is Satoshi Nakamoto, creator of Bitcoin, in a move that prevents him from bringing further lawsuits in the country.
articles.content: Weve seen a cascading effect from the pronouncement on a host of other litigations globally, says Grewal. For people outside of crypto, [all this] might sound cartoonish. But with Wrights claims fall… [+3320 chars]

articles.author: Joel Khalili
articles.title: FTX Creditors Say Payout Deal Is 'an Insult'—and Plan to Revolt
articles.description: FTX has a plan to repay its former crypto customers more than the billions of dollars they lost in the latest bankruptcy proposal. But some will reject it anyway.
articles.content: Some creditors of the bankrupt crypto exchange FTX are preparing to reject a plan that would see them recover 118 percent of the money they lost. The proposal is far less generous than it might seem,… [+2945 chars]
